Colin wrote:

>Have you read the Modular NEAT paper? Sounds similar except your labels
>could be used to connect up disperate networks right, whereas Mod. NEAT
>modules always connect between the input and output layers, they don;t
>connect to each other.

Yes, I was in the discussion we had here a few months ago.

ISRT the Modular NEAT paper did use labels, but they were explicit, not 
evolving (e.g. the label said "I connect to (1,3)").  That works fine as 
long as every "concept" that the system might want to label exists from the 
start.  The idea behind arbitrary labels is that new concepts can evolve as 
required.

Mod Neat with module to module connections was something I suggested at the 
time.

However, in the domain used for that paper there's also the question of the 
symmetry of the board.  If a ALS/modular system worked, then it should be 
able to evolve it's own systems to exploit the symmetry (e.g. the same 
arrangement of pieces on a different part of the board should use the same 
module).  But who knows how long that might take.  As an alternative, one 
could build some understanding of symmetry into the system from the 
first.  That would involve a different idea, where connections to modules 
contain relative positions.  Such as:

connection#1 :  Any Square
connection#2 : LeftOf(Connection#1)
connection#3 : Above(Connection#1)

...

Which is another strand in the stuff I'm writing up.  The use of simple 
pattern-recognition to connect modules in a smart manner.  It's just the 
extension of the ALS, e.g. if an output from one module consists of more 
than one channel and they both need to be wired up, then the labels on the 
receiving module can read something like:

connection#1 : concept-A
connection#2 : concept-B from the same place as connection#1

Which would serve to pass X and Y coordinates around together...

         Ian
